words.latinSentence: Marcus advenit ad scholam mane.
words.englishSentence: Marcus arrives at school in the morning.

words.latinSentence: In urbe novum aedificium magnum stat.
words.englishSentence: In the city, a new large building stands.

words.latinSentence: Puella aeger domi manet propter febrem.
words.englishSentence: The girl stays at home because she is sick.

words.latinSentence: Duo discipuli sunt; alter in classe sedet.
words.englishSentence: There are two students; the other sits in the classroom.

words.latinSentence: Magistra cantat carmen laetum in aula.
words.englishSentence: The teacher sings a joyful song in the hall.

words.latinSentence: Cēterī discipuli in hortō ludunt.
words.englishSentence: The rest of the students play in the garden.

words.latinSentence: Custōs domūs portas diligenter custōdit.
words.englishSentence: The guard diligently watches over the house's doors.

words.latinSentence: Senex dīcit verba sapientia ad discipulos.
words.englishSentence: The old man speaks words of wisdom to the students.

words.latinSentence: Solis radii excitant aves in silvā tranquilla.
words.englishSentence: The sun's rays wake up the birds in the peaceful forest.

words.latinSentence: Puer fessus post longam cursum requiescit.
words.englishSentence: The boy rests after a long run, tired.

words.latinSentence: In bello crudeli, hostem interfecit in proelio.
words.englishSentence: In a cruel war, he killed the enemy in battle.

words.latinSentence: Ita vērō, respondit magistratus cum gaudio.
words.englishSentence: ‘Yes indeed,’ replied the officer with joy.

words.latinSentence: Discipulus nōlō lūdere in hora longa.
words.englishSentence: The student does not want to play during a long hour.

words.latinSentence: Librum novum magister discipulis ostendit.
words.englishSentence: The teacher shows the students a new book.

words.latinSentence: Nūllus vir audax in pugna apparuit.
words.englishSentence: No brave man appeared in the fight.

words.latinSentence: Magister dicit, 'Possum docere et vos discitis.'
words.englishSentence: The teacher says, 'I can teach, and you learn.'

words.latinSentence: Discipulus ruit ad scholam cum celeritate.
words.englishSentence: The student rushes to school with speed.

words.latinSentence: Puer sē curat in ludo et in schola.
words.englishSentence: The boy takes care of himself both in play and at school.

words.latinSentence: Servus trahit sacculos frumenti ad culinam.
words.englishSentence: The slave drags sacks of grain to the kitchen.

words.latinSentence: Vīta pulchra est, dicit poeta laetus.
words.englishSentence: Life is beautiful, says the joyful poet.

words.latinSentence: Ego volō linguam Latinam discere.
words.englishSentence: I want to learn the Latin language.

words.latinSentence: Bellator vulnerat hostem cum gladio firmo.
words.englishSentence: The warrior wounds the enemy with a strong sword.

words.latinSentence: Aliquid mirabile in silvā reperitur.
words.englishSentence: Something wonderful is found in the forest.

words.latinSentence: Discipuli congregantur apud domum magistrī.
words.englishSentence: The students gather at the teacher's house.

words.latinSentence: Puer attonitus est de nova fabula in schola.
words.englishSentence: The boy is astonished by the new story at school.

words.latinSentence: Aula regia splendida est sub sole.
words.englishSentence: The royal palace is splendid under the sun.

words.latinSentence: Discipuli cotīdiē in schola laborant.
words.englishSentence: The students work every day at school.

words.latinSentence: Vestimenta decōra in convivio geruntur.
words.englishSentence: Proper garments are worn at the banquet.

words.latinSentence: Exercitus dēlet oppidum hostium cum vi.
words.englishSentence: The army destroys the enemy town with force.

words.latinSentence: Deus magnus in caelo regnat.
words.englishSentence: The great god reigns in the sky.

words.latinSentence: Exercitatio difficilis discipulos provocat.
words.englishSentence: The difficult exercise challenges the students.

words.latinSentence: Magister dīligenter libros legendos ordinet.
words.englishSentence: The teacher carefully arranges the books to be read.

words.latinSentence: Domina domūs hospitium pulchrum curat.
words.englishSentence: The mistress of the house takes care of the beautiful guesthouse.

words.latinSentence: Puer dōnum parvum a matre accepit.
words.englishSentence: The boy received a small gift from his mother.

words.latinSentence: Canis fidēlis dominum suum sequitur.
words.englishSentence: The faithful dog follows its master.

words.latinSentence: Puella ipsa vestimenta sua eligit.
words.englishSentence: The girl herself chooses her clothes.

words.latinSentence: Iste liber veterānus in bibliotheca iacet.
words.englishSentence: That old book lies in the library.

words.latinSentence: Marītus familiam suam diligenter curat.
words.englishSentence: The husband diligently takes care of his family.

words.latinSentence: Est necesse discipuli nova verba discere.
words.englishSentence: It is necessary for the students to learn new words.

words.latinSentence: Num hoc verum est?
words.englishSentence: Surely... not, is this true?

words.latinSentence: Quam pulcher est hortus sub sole splendenti!
words.englishSentence: How beautiful is the garden in the shining sun!

words.latinSentence: Quamquam pluit, discipuli in ludo manent.
words.englishSentence: Although it is raining, the students remain in the play area.

words.latinSentence: Magisterque discipuli diligenter audiunt.
words.englishSentence: Both the teacher and the students listen attentively.

words.latinSentence: Rēx imperium magnum super populum habet.
words.englishSentence: The king has a great empire over the people.

words.latinSentence: Ubi discipuli conveniunt, sermo incipit.
words.englishSentence: When the students gather, conversation begins.

words.latinSentence: Agmen militum per viam urbis procedit.
words.englishSentence: A column of soldiers marches along the city street.

words.latinSentence: Alius discipulus librum novum legit.
words.englishSentence: Another student reads a new book.

words.latinSentence: Aqua frigida in puteo abundat.
words.englishSentence: Cold water abounds in the well.

words.latinSentence: Magister fenestram claudit ad silentium.
words.englishSentence: The teacher shuts the window for silence.

words.latinSentence: Locus commodus ad studium est.
words.englishSentence: The place is convenient for studying.

words.latinSentence: Discipulus dēbet operam tradere magistro.
words.englishSentence: The student ought to show respect to the teacher.

words.latinSentence: Equus nobilis in agris currit.
words.englishSentence: The noble horse runs in the fields.

words.latinSentence: Et etiam puella in ludo laeta ridet.
words.englishSentence: Even the girl smiles happily at play.

words.latinSentence: Pluvia impediit viam magistrī ambulare.
words.englishSentence: The rain hinders the teacher's walk.

words.latinSentence: Lectus vetus in triclinium iacet.
words.englishSentence: The old couch lies in the dining room.

words.latinSentence: Puer lentē ambulat per hortum virentem.
words.englishSentence: The boy walks slowly through the green garden.

words.latinSentence: Lītus aureum sub sole splendet.
words.englishSentence: The golden sea-shore shines under the sun.

words.latinSentence: Mare vastum fluctuat in tempore ventoso.
words.englishSentence: The vast sea roils in a windy time.

words.latinSentence: Puer miser in via ambulat.
words.englishSentence: The wretched boy walks on the street.

words.latinSentence: Nauta fortis in mari navigat.
words.englishSentence: The brave sailor sails in the sea.

words.latinSentence: Prīnceps exercitus ordinem ducit.
words.englishSentence: The chief of the army leads the formation.

words.latinSentence: Quī ad cenam venit, laetitiam affert.
words.englishSentence: Whoever comes to dinner brings joy.

words.latinSentence: Discipulus redeit ad domum post scholam.
words.englishSentence: The student returns home after school.

words.latinSentence: Sacerdōs templi ritus sacros egit.
words.englishSentence: The priest performed the sacred rites of the temple.

words.latinSentence: Magister teneat librum in manu.
words.englishSentence: The teacher holds the book in his hand.

words.latinSentence: Unda magna in mari impetu agit.
words.englishSentence: A great wave roils in the sea.

words.latinSentence: Exercitus vincit hostes in proelio.
words.englishSentence: The army wins over the enemies in battle.

words.latinSentence: Operā aedificat nova domus in oppido.
words.englishSentence: With effort, a new house is built in the town.

words.latinSentence: Amicus auxilium praebet in difficultate.
words.englishSentence: The friend provides help in difficulty.

words.latinSentence: Discipulus bonus semper studet diligenter.
words.englishSentence: A good student always studies diligently.

words.latinSentence: Magister cōnsentit cum discipulīs de regula novā.
words.englishSentence: The teacher agrees with the students about the new rule.

words.latinSentence: Cōnsilium sapientis in schola disputatur.
words.englishSentence: The plan of the wise man is discussed at school.

words.latinSentence: Deinde discipuli ad ludum eunt.
words.englishSentence: Then the students go to play.

words.latinSentence: Puella dēlectat auditu musicae in aula.
words.englishSentence: The girl delights in hearing music in the hall.

words.latinSentence: Canis effugit ex cavea parva.
words.englishSentence: The dog escapes from the small pen.

words.latinSentence: Flōs ruber in horto magnificus crescit.
words.englishSentence: The red flower grows magnificently in the garden.

words.latinSentence: Imperātor imperium suum largitur populō.
words.englishSentence: The emperor bestows his empire upon the people.

words.latinSentence: Discipuli inter se colloquuntur in schola.
words.englishSentence: The students talk among themselves at school.

words.latinSentence: Ita discipuli legunt libros cum cura.
words.englishSentence: In this way, the students read books with care.

words.latinSentence: Dies melior ad ludendum post studium venit.
words.englishSentence: A better day for playing comes after study.

words.latinSentence: Nauta nāvigat per mare clarum.
words.englishSentence: The sailor sails through the clear sea.

words.latinSentence: Nōnne discipuli diligenter laborant?
words.englishSentence: Surely, the students work diligently?

words.latinSentence: Bellum crudele multos hominēs perit.
words.englishSentence: In the cruel war, many men perish.

words.latinSentence: Magister pōnit libros in mensā ordinatos.
words.englishSentence: The teacher places the books orderly on the table.

words.latinSentence: Postrīdiē discipuli ad scholam revertuntur.
words.englishSentence: On the next day, the students return to school.

words.latinSentence: Magister pūnit discipulum pro errore parvo.
words.englishSentence: The teacher punishes the student for a small mistake.

words.latinSentence: Simulac sol oritur, discipuli currunt ad scholam.
words.englishSentence: As soon as the sun rises, the students run to school.

words.latinSentence: Summus honor in schola ad discipulos datur.
words.englishSentence: The highest honor in school is given to the students.

words.latinSentence: Magister tollit pennam ad scribendum in tabulā.
words.englishSentence: The teacher lifts the pen to write on the board.

words.latinSentence: Puer vertit librum ad paginam novam legendam.
words.englishSentence: The boy turns the book to a new page to read.

words.latinSentence: Librum ā discipulo ad magistrum tradit.
words.englishSentence: The book is handed from the student to the teacher.

words.latinSentence: Animus fortis in periculis manet firmus.
words.englishSentence: A brave spirit remains steadfast in dangers.

words.latinSentence: Discipulus appropinquat ad magistrum cum quaestione.
words.englishSentence: The student comes near to the teacher with a question.

words.latinSentence: Āra in templo sacrum ornata est floribus.
words.englishSentence: The altar in the temple is adorned with flowers.

words.latinSentence: Discipuli bene laborant in schola.
words.englishSentence: The students work well at school.

words.latinSentence: Magister benignus discipulis semper auxilium dat.
words.englishSentence: The kind teacher always gives help to the students.

words.latinSentence: Diū discipuli in schola manent ad studendum.
words.englishSentence: The students remain at school for a long time to study.

words.latinSentence: Faber diligens multās res ex lignō facit.
words.englishSentence: The craftsman makes many things out of wood.

words.latinSentence: Exercitium facile videtur ad discipulos.
words.englishSentence: The exercise seems easy to the students.

words.latinSentence: Discipuli graviter de lectione cogitant.
words.englishSentence: The students think seriously about the lesson.

words.latinSentence: Hīc locum conveniunt omnes discipuli.
words.englishSentence: Here, all the students gather.

words.latinSentence: Inepta īnsula in mari remota iacet.
words.englishSentence: A deserted island lies in the remote sea.

words.latinSentence: Discipulus invītus nova verba discit.
words.englishSentence: The student learns new words unwillingly.

words.latinSentence: Itaque magister verba clara explicat.
words.englishSentence: And so, the teacher explains the clear words.

words.latinSentence: Puer videt maximam statuam in foro.
words.englishSentence: The boy sees a very big statue in the market.

words.latinSentence: Negōtium familiae in urbe floruit.
words.englishSentence: The family's business flourishes in the city.

words.latinSentence: Numquam discipuli absentiam faciunt.
words.englishSentence: The students are never absent.

words.latinSentence: Paucī discipuli in aula laeti sedere solent.
words.englishSentence: Few students are accustomed to sitting happily in the hall.

words.latinSentence: Discipulus pervenit ad finem cursus scholāsticus.
words.englishSentence: The student reaches the end of the school course.

words.latinSentence: Quondam puella narravit fabulam mirabilem.
words.englishSentence: Once, a girl told a wonderful story.

words.latinSentence: Magister recipit librum a discipulo diligenter.
words.englishSentence: The teacher takes back the book from the student carefully.

words.latinSentence: Hostes resistunt copiis fortibus in proelio.
words.englishSentence: The enemies resist with strong forces in battle.

words.latinSentence: Discipulus audet se in viā novā experīrī.
words.englishSentence: The student dares to try himself on a new path.

words.latinSentence: Caput veterae statuae in museo splendide lucet.
words.englishSentence: The head of the ancient statue shines splendidly in the museum.

words.latinSentence: Discipulus coepit novum studium audīre.
words.englishSentence: The student began to listen to the new lesson.

words.latinSentence: Magister cognoscit multos discipulōs novos.
words.englishSentence: The teacher gets to know many new students.

words.latinSentence: Dea pulchra in templo veneratur.
words.englishSentence: The beautiful goddess is revered in the temple.

words.latinSentence: Magister dēmōnstrat figuram in charta.
words.englishSentence: The teacher shows the figure on the chart.

words.latinSentence: Puer discēdit ex schola post lectionem.
words.englishSentence: The boy leaves the school after the lesson.

words.latinSentence: Fortasse discipulī ventūrī sunt ad cenam.
words.englishSentence: Perhaps the students will come to dinner.

words.latinSentence: Ibi in horto lilia alba florent.
words.englishSentence: There in the garden, white lilies bloom.

words.latinSentence: Magister libenter respondit quaestionibus discipulōrum.
words.englishSentence: The teacher gladly answered the students' questions.

words.latinSentence: Manus diligens librum tenet discipulus.
words.englishSentence: The diligent student holds the book in his hand.

words.latinSentence: Mīles fortis in acie strenue pugnat.
words.englishSentence: The brave soldier fights valiantly in the battle line.

words.latinSentence: Nam veritas semper in corde manet.
words.englishSentence: For truth always remains in the heart.

words.latinSentence: Nēmō in schola tam diligenter studet.
words.englishSentence: No one studies so diligently in school.

words.latinSentence: Lapides viam obstant in hortō.
words.englishSentence: Stones block the way in the garden.

words.latinSentence: Pars libri difficilis sed pulchra est.
words.englishSentence: A part of the book is difficult but beautiful.

words.latinSentence: Discipulus petit auxilium a magistro.
words.englishSentence: The student asks for help from the teacher.

words.latinSentence: Posteā omnes discipuli cenam habent.
words.englishSentence: Afterwards, all the students have dinner.

words.latinSentence: Magister stetit prō scriniā antīquo.
words.englishSentence: The teacher stood in front of the ancient cabinet.

words.latinSentence: Quō iter incipit discipulus in viā longa?
words.englishSentence: Where does the student begin his long journey?

words.latinSentence: Discipulus recūsat audīre praecepta dura.
words.englishSentence: The student refuses to listen to harsh instructions.

words.latinSentence: Discipulī soleunt studēre quotidie diligenter.
words.englishSentence: The students are accustomed to studying diligently every day.

words.latinSentence: Discipulus amāt patriam suam sincēre.
words.englishSentence: The student loves his country sincerely.

words.latinSentence: Mater cāra fīliam suam semper amat.
words.englishSentence: The mother always loves her dear daughter.

words.latinSentence: Magister cōgitat de novā lectione diligenter.
words.englishSentence: The teacher thinks carefully about the new lesson.

words.latinSentence: Discipulus comparat instrumenta ad scholam.
words.englishSentence: The student obtains the supplies for school.

words.latinSentence: Magister cōnficiit lectionem cum disciplina.
words.englishSentence: The teacher finishes the lesson with discipline.

words.latinSentence: Domina cūrā filios suos cum amore.
words.englishSentence: The mistress looks after her children with love.

words.latinSentence: Fīlia pulchra in horto ludit cum amīcīs.
words.englishSentence: The beautiful daughter plays in the garden with friends.

words.latinSentence: Flumen lentē fluat per agrum virentem.
words.englishSentence: The river flows slowly through the green field.

words.latinSentence: Forte discipulus invenit librum vetus in foro.
words.englishSentence: By chance, the student found an old book in the market.

words.latinSentence: Grātiās agō magistrō pro docēndō sapientiā.
words.englishSentence: I thank the teacher for teaching with wisdom.

words.latinSentence: Miles hasta validā in proelio gerit.
words.englishSentence: The soldier carries a strong spear in battle.

words.latinSentence: Discipulī ambulant illīc ad scholam antīquam.
words.englishSentence: The students walk there to the old school.

words.latinSentence: Iter longum per silvas et montes durat.
words.englishSentence: The long journey lasts through forests and mountains.

words.latinSentence: Locus secretus in silva invenitur.
words.englishSentence: A secret place is found in the forest.

words.latinSentence: Māne discipulī ad scholam properant.
words.englishSentence: In the morning, the students hurry to school.

words.latinSentence: Nōvī multās res ex lectione discendae esse.
words.englishSentence: I know there is much to learn from the lesson.

words.latinSentence: Perīculum magnum in viā manifestum est.
words.englishSentence: A great danger is evident on the road.

words.latinSentence: Plūrimī discipulī in schola congregantur.
words.englishSentence: Very many students gather at school.

words.latinSentence: Magister poscit auxilium ab omnibus discipulīs.
words.englishSentence: The teacher demands help from all the students.

words.latinSentence: Tot librī in bibliotheca inveniri possunt.
words.englishSentence: So many books can be found in the library.

words.latinSentence: Puer parvus vexat fratrēs suos in ludo.
words.englishSentence: The little boy annoys his brothers during play.

words.latinSentence: Multi vīvunt in urbe magna cum spe.
words.englishSentence: Many live in the great city with hope.

words.latinSentence: Discipulī vix audiunt verba magistrī.
words.englishSentence: The students hardly hear the teacher's words.

words.latinSentence: Vōx clara in theatrō resonat ad laudem.
words.englishSentence: A clear voice resounds in the theatre in praise.

words.latinSentence: Discipulus adeit ad magistrum cum quaestione.
words.englishSentence: The student goes up to the teacher with a question.

words.latinSentence: Imperator arcessit duces ad consilium.
words.englishSentence: The emperor summoned the generals for counsel.

words.latinSentence: Ars pulchra in museo exponitur.
words.englishSentence: Beautiful art is exhibited in the museum.

words.latinSentence: Dominus crūdēlis discipulōs severē castigat.
words.englishSentence: The cruel master severely punishes the students.

words.latinSentence: Dēnique dies festus finem habet in urbe.
words.englishSentence: At last, the festive day comes to an end in the city.

words.latinSentence: Populus dēsperat sub imperio crudeli.
words.englishSentence: The people despair under a cruel regime.

words.latinSentence: Vir doctus saepe consilia utilia dat.
words.englishSentence: The learned man often gives useful advice.

words.latinSentence: Domus antiqua plena est memorabilium.
words.englishSentence: The ancient home is full of memories.

words.latinSentence: Magister īnferit novas res ad lectionem.
words.englishSentence: The teacher brings in new materials for the lesson.

words.latinSentence: Servus līberat captīvum post longum tempus.
words.englishSentence: The slave sets the captive free after a long time.

words.latinSentence: Lūna plena lucet in caelo sereno.
words.englishSentence: The full moon shines in the serene sky.

words.latinSentence: Mors inevitabilis omnibus contingit.
words.englishSentence: Death is inevitable for all.

words.latinSentence: Oculus discipulī perspicuus novam rem videt.
words.englishSentence: The student's eye clearly sees something new.

words.latinSentence: Magister conatur discipulōs persuādēre de labore.
words.englishSentence: The teacher tries to persuade the students about the work.

words.latinSentence: Dies pessimus adulescentibus fastidiosus est.
words.englishSentence: The day is very bad and unpleasant for the young.

words.latinSentence: Magister relinquit librum veterem in aula.
words.englishSentence: The teacher leaves the old book in the hall.

words.latinSentence: Sīcut avis volat, discipulus librum legit.
words.englishSentence: Just as a bird flies, the student reads a book.

words.latinSentence: Discipulus tam diligenter laborat ut laude mereret.
words.englishSentence: The student works so diligently that he deserves praise.

words.latinSentence: Magister temptat novas methodos docendi.
words.englishSentence: The teacher tries new methods of teaching.

words.latinSentence: Gladius vulnerat hostem in proelio acerbo.
words.englishSentence: The sword wounds the enemy in the fierce battle.

words.latinSentence: Discipulus ūnus solus librum legit.
words.englishSentence: One student reads the book alone.

words.latinSentence: Duo discipuli in aula collocuti sunt.
words.englishSentence: Two students were conversing in the hall.

words.latinSentence: Trēs pueri in horto ludunt laeti.
words.englishSentence: Three boys play happily in the garden.

words.latinSentence: Quattuor fabulae in librō memorabiles sunt.
words.englishSentence: Four stories in the book are memorable.

words.latinSentence: Quīnque discipuli librum novum acquirunt.
words.englishSentence: Five students acquire a new book.

words.latinSentence: Sex mīlēs in acie fortiter pugnant.
words.englishSentence: Six soldiers fight valiantly in the battle line.

words.latinSentence: Septem dies in hebdomadā labōrant discipuli.
words.englishSentence: The students work for seven days in the week.

words.latinSentence: Octō librī in bibliotheca ordinantur.
words.englishSentence: Eight books are arranged in the library.

words.latinSentence: Novem flores in vase pulchre sunt.
words.englishSentence: Nine flowers are beautiful in the vase.

words.latinSentence: Decem discipuli in schola numerantur.
words.englishSentence: Ten students are counted in the school.

words.latinSentence: Vīgintī ludi in theatrō recitari solent.
words.englishSentence: Twenty plays are usually performed in the theatre.

words.latinSentence: Trīgintā hominēs in forum congregantur.
words.englishSentence: Thirty people gather in the market.

words.latinSentence: Quadrāgintā annī senectūtis signum sunt.
words.englishSentence: Forty years are a sign of old age.

words.latinSentence: Quīnquāgintā discipuli in schola discunt.
words.englishSentence: Fifty students study in the school.
